be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.core

Class User

  • java.lang.Object
    • be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.core.User
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<java.util.concurrent.Delayed>, java.lang.Runnable, java.util.concurrent.Delayed
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DistributedTestUser, EvilTester, RemoteTestUser, SocketUser, StopTestUser, TestUser, TimingTestUser

    public abstract class User
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable, java.util.concurrent.Delayed

    The User class represents abstract user objects that simulate the intended user behavior for the system under test. All scalability analysis results are relative to the behavior exhibited by the user objects. A typical scalability analysis will introduce one concrete user type that extends User. However, multiple concrete user types can be used at the same time: The configuration file allows specifying the ratios at which different user implementations should contribute to the overall generated load. See the example configuration file for more information.

    A User object is executed in its own thread. Its behavior is encoded by overriding the goFetch method.

    A User interacts with the system under test via Requests. Per type of interaction (e.g., logging in, requesting a resource, ...), a new Request type should be created. Quality of service results (i.e., breakdown of residence times) are provided per concrete Request type.

    Author:
    Thomas Heyman
    See Also:
    Request

    • Constructor Detail

      • User

        public User(UserPool pool)
        Main constructor of a user object. A user receives a reference to the DataProvider chain, as well as the active Plugin chain, during initialisation. Configuration options will be read from the data object during initialisation. When overriding this constructor in a subclass, simply call super with the provided data and plugin objects.

    • Method Detail

      • random

        public java.util.Random random()
        The random generator for this user. For efficiency reasons, this method should be used as the standard source of randomness for a user object.
        Returns:
        A java.util.Random generator.

      • username

        public java.lang.String username()
        Returns the user name of this user object, which should be used to log into, or otherwise access, the system under test. Note that user names are automatically assigned based on the template specified in the configuration file. The user name of a user object does not change.
        Returns:
        The user name of this user object.

      • password

        public java.lang.String password()
        Returns the password of this user object, which should be used to log into, or otherwise access, the system under test. Note that passwords are automatically assigned based on the template specified in the configuration file, so that the username/password combination conforms to the specified configuration template. The password of a user object does not change.
        Returns:
        The password of this user object.

      • targetUrl

        public java.lang.String targetUrl()
        The URL of the system under test. When sticky load balancing is enabled, this method always returns the same value. When sticky load balancing is disabled and there are multiple hosts specified in the configuration file, the value returned by host() might change between different calls of this method.
        Returns:
        The URL of the system under test, as specified in the configuration file.

      • data

        public DataProvider data()
        Returns the chain of data providers which can be used to get and put values, as well as lock values to provide synchronisation. Data providers as specified in the configuration file are reflectively loaded and chained in the order in which they appear in the configuration file. Requests to data() are passed along the chain and handled by the first DataProvider instance that is able to do so.
        Returns:
        The DataProvider subsystem.

      • hasRun

        public boolean hasRun()
        Checks whether this user has been scheduled for execution at least once. If false, this user has not performed any work yet.
        Returns:
        True when this user has started running in a thread at least once.

      • contributesToLoad

        public final boolean contributesToLoad()
        Indicates whether the load produced by this user should be counted when calculating the total load at the end of an experiment. By default, a user's load contributes to the total load. However, in some cases, specific users can be added to an experiment to create a representative context, while not contributing to the total load. For instance, all users that are prestarted (see the configuration option "user_implementations_prestart" are not considered contributors, so in their case this method would return false. Each user can change whether it contributes via setContributesToLoad(boolean).
        Returns:
        Whether the load generated by this user should be considered when calculating experimental results.

      • setContributesToLoad

        public void setContributesToLoad(boolean contributes)
        Sets whether the load generated by this user is considered while calculating overall results. See contributesToLoad().
        Parameters:
        contributes - Whether the load produced by this user is considered.

      • plugin

        public final Plugin plugin()
        Returns a chain of plugin objects that handle overall platform functionality. This functionality is mainly used in the (automated) handling of user requests, and is not directly intended for end users.
        Returns:
        The chain of loaded plugin objects.

      • requests

        public final java.util.ArrayList<Request> requests()
        Returns all requests that have been created by this user object and that are kept into account. Note that only the requests which are explicitly kept into account are retained, the others are discarded after use. See keepAccountOfRequest for additional information.
        Returns:
        An arraylist of all requests issued by this user that are taken into account.

      • isMeasuring

        public final boolean isMeasuring()
        Checks whether the user object is currently measuring. A user that is measuring ensures that all requests that are created during the measuring period will be considered statistically relevant (see Request.statisticallyRelevant()). Furthermore, all iterations of mainLoop() that terminate within this period are counted towards the overall capacity of the system under test. Finally, all iterations of mainLoop() that are started within the measuring period with an unacceptable delay (i.e., later than 1.05 * fetch_delay after the previous iteration of mainLoop() was terminated) will be marked as too slow (see slowCount()).
        Returns:
        Whether the user object is currently measuring and its results are statistically relevant.

      • getThinkTime

        public int getThinkTime()
        Returns the "think time", i.e., the time this user is currently waiting in between iteration of its mainLoop().
        Returns:
        The "think time" in milliseconds.

      • getEffectiveThinkTime

        public long getEffectiveThinkTime()
        Returns the effective think time that this user actually spent waiting before having executed its mainLoop(). This method returns an effective time in nanoseconds if the mainLoop() has been executed at least once and has been run again after that (see run()). The value is updated every time the user is run again after that.
        Returns:
        The effective time in nanoseconds that the user spent waiting inbetween its two previous runs, or 0 if it has not run at least twice.

      • loopCount

        public final int loopCount()
        Returns the number of times that this user's mainLoop() method has successfully been terminated within the current measuring period, as defined by isMeasuring(). This value is used to determine the capacity of the system under test. Note that the counter only counts successful mainLoop() iterations, i.e., those that do not throw an exception. On the other hand, the success of a mainLoop() iteration does not depend on the outcome of the requests issued. For instance, if an IOException is thrown during the execution of mainLoop() while isMeasuring(), loopCount() is not incremented. On the other hand, if mainLoop() successfully terminates but all requests from that iteration have failed, loopCount() is incremented.
        Returns:
        The number of times that mainLoop() has successfully terminated within the current isMeasuring() period.

      • slowCount

        public final int slowCount()
        Returns the number of times that this user's mainLoop() method was started too slow within the current measuring period, as defined by isMeasuring(). Too slow is defined as later than 1.05 * fetch_delay. This value is printed as part of the final experimental result, and should be kept as low as possible. High values (i.e., more than a couple %) indicate that Scalar is becoming the bottleneck in the current scalability analysis, and subsequent results are no longer relevant. In that case, consider deploying Scalar on more nodes, and reduce the user peak load per node, or refactor mainLoop().
        Returns:
        The number of times mainLoop() was started too slow in the current measuring period.

      • keepAccountOfRequest

        public final void keepAccountOfRequest(Request r)
        Indicates that the provided Request object should be taken into account by this user, and considered during statistics generation. If a Request is not kept into account, it will be discarded after use. Note that this method should not be called directly; instead, use the boolean flag in the constructor Request.Request(User, boolean).
        Parameters:
        r - The Request to keep account of.

      • isKeepingAccountOfRequest

        public final boolean isKeepingAccountOfRequest(Request r)
        Verifies whether this user object is keeping account of a Request r. See also keepAccountOfRequest(Request).
        Parameters:
        r - The Request to check whether it is being kept into account by this user.
        Returns:
        True when r is being kept into account by this user, false otherwise.

      • mainLoop

        public abstract void mainLoop()
                       throws DataException,
                              RequestException
        The main loop of this user, which encodes user behavior. This method contains the "business flow" that the user should follow to successfully interact with the system under test. One execution of this method counts as one successful user interaction: If isMeasuring() when this method terminates successfully, loopCount() will be incremented by one. Note that the capacity of the system under test is determined by the number of times that this method completes, *not* by the number of requests that are created by this method. For instance, if one successful interaction with the system under test involves steps A *and* B, then one successful completion of mainLoop() still only counts for one "user interaction", even though two Request objects, one for A and one for B, might have been created. Conversely, if one "user interaction" consists of step A *or* step B, then the implementation of mainLoop() should take care to alternate between generating a Request for A and one for B in different executions of mainLoop(). Throwing any exception from within this method will have as effect that that iteration is not counted in the overall total. The exception will be logged. Failures to interact with the system under test should be handled by setting an appropriate result status for any issued Request objects (see Request.done(be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.requests.RequestResult)).
        Throws:
        DataException
        RequestException

      • run

        public final void run()
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable

      • markStartRun

        public void markStartRun(long startTime)

      • onStop

        public void onStop()
        Method for cleaning up after an experimental run. This method is called automatically when an experimental run is finished (potentially multiple times per experiment, depending on the configuration). Override this method to implement cleanup behavior (e.g., logging out after an experiment, releasing resources, etc.). Note that this method is not necessarily called when an experiment is terminated abnormally (e.g., when the master is killed with ^C). For more advanced life cycle management, implement a Plugin.
